title: Second Law of Thermo - thermal equilibrium

content.question: Blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are made of the same material, and have identical sizes, shapes, and masses. Blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are initially at temperatures of <math alttext="300 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, <math alttext="250 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>250</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="450 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>450</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math> when the blocks are placed in direct contact with each other and isolated from their surroundings, as shown. The three-block system eventually reaches thermal equilibrium. Which of the following correctly describes the change, if any, in the entropy of the three-block system?

choices.label: The entropy decreases until it reaches a constant value.
The entropy increases until it reaches a constant value.
The entropy change cannot be known without knowing the initial entropies of each individual block.

content.answer: The entropy increases until it reaches a constant value.
